docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: PART 3 JURISDICTION OF, AND PROCEEDINGS BEFORE, THE TRIBUNAL [ss 10–32]

heading.title: PART 3 JURISDICTION OF, AND PROCEEDINGS BEFORE, THE TRIBUNAL [ss 10–32]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 3 JURISDICTION OF, AND PROCEEDINGS BEFORE, THE TRIBUNAL [ss 10–32]

leg:heading.title: JURISDICTION OF, AND PROCEEDINGS BEFORE, THE TRIBUNAL [ss 10–32]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,255] s 10 Jurisdiction and functions of the Tribunal

leg:heading.title: Jurisdiction and functions of the Tribunal

p.text: The Tribunal has, except as provided by sections 29 and 32 , exclusive jurisdiction to hear and determine proceedings referred to in sections 11 and 12 .
The Tribunal has such other jurisdiction as may be conferred on it by or under any other Act.
The Tribunal has, wherever sitting, jurisdiction throughout New South Wales.

In any proceedings brought under section 11 or transferred under section 12 , the Tribunal has the same power to make decisions as the Supreme Court would, but for this section, have had in relation to similar proceedings brought in the Supreme Court.
Subject to sections 13(6) and 14 , a decision of the Tribunal has the same effect as, and may be enforced in the same way as, a decision of the Supreme Court.

The following matters are declared to be excluded matters for the purposes of section 5F of the Corporations Act 2001 of the Commonwealth in relation to the provisions of sections 471B and 500(2) of that Act:
proceedings under section 11 of this Act,
proceedings transferred under section 12 of this Act,

being proceedings that, but for this subsection, could not be commenced or proceeded with without the leave of the Court referred to in sections 471B or 500(2) of the Corporations Act 2001 of the Commonwealth.

In the absence of this subsection, sections 471B and 500(2) of the Corporations Act 2001 of the Commonwealth would require the leave of the Federal Court or the Supreme Court to commence or proceed with proceedings under this Act against certain companies that are being externally administered. This section ensures that section 5F of that Act will operate to ensure that those sections will not require the leave of the Court directing the external administration before proceedings can be commenced or proceeded with in the Tribunal.
[subs (6) subst Act 34 of 2001 s 3 and Sch 2 effective 15 July 2001; am Act 112 of 2001 s 3 and Sch 2 effective 15 July 2001]

Proceedings to which subsection (6) refers are declared to be an applied Corporations legislation matter for the purposes of Part 3 of the Corporations (Ancillary Provisions) Act 2001 in relation to sections 471B and 500(2) of the Corporations Act 2001 of the Commonwealth as if a reference in those sections to the Court were a reference to the Tribunal.

Part 3 of the Corporations (Ancillary Provisions) Act 2001 provides for the application of provisions of the Corporations Act 2001 and Part 3 of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 2001 of the Commonwealth as laws of the State in respect of any matter declared by a law of the State (whether with or without modification) to be an applied Corporations legislation matter for the purposes of that Part in relation to those Commonwealth provisions. Section 14(2) of the Corporations (Ancillary Provisions) Act 2001 ensures that a declaration made for the purposes of Part 3 of that Act only operates to apply a provision of the Corporations legislation to a matter as a law of the State if that provision does not already apply to the matter as a law of the Commonwealth. If a provision referred to in a declaration already applies as a law of the Commonwealth, nothing in the declaration will affect its continued operation as a law of the Commonwealth.
[subs (7) insrt Act 34 of 2001 s 3 and Sch 2 effective 15 July 2001]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,260] s 11 Claims for damages for dust diseases etc to be brought under this Act

leg:heading.title: Claims for damages for dust diseases etc to be brought under this Act

p.text: If:
a person is suffering, or has suffered, from a dust-related condition or a person who has died was, immediately before death, suffering from a dust-related condition, and
it is alleged that the dust-related condition was attributable or partly attributable to a breach of a duty owed to the person by another person, and

the person who is or was suffering from the dust-related condition or a person claiming through that person would, but for this Act, have been entitled to bring an action for the recovery of damages in respect of that dust-related condition or death,
proceedings for damages in respect of that dust-related condition or death may be brought before the Tribunal and may not be brought or entertained before any other court or tribunal.

Proceedings by any tort-feasor liable in respect of damages referred to in subsection (1) to recover contribution from any other tort-feasor liable in respect of that damage may be brought before the Tribunal.
This subsection does not prevent those proceedings being brought in another court.
[subs (1A) insrt Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 1 July 2005]
In subsection (1) , a reference to a duty includes a reference to a duty imposed by statute as well as a duty imposed under the common law.

If the cause of action giving rise to proceedings to be brought under subsection (1) or (1A) also gives rise to a claim in respect of some other matter, the claim may be included in those proceedings even though it does not relate to a dust-related condition from which a person is suffering or has suffered.
[subs (3) am Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 1 July 2005]
Any matter that is ancillary or related to a matter that is the subject of proceedings to be brought under subsection (1) or (1A) may also be included in those proceedings.
[subs (4) am Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 1 July 2005]

In subsection (1)(c) , the reference to a person claiming through a person who is or was suffering from a dust-related condition includes a reference to a relative for whose benefit an action may be brought under the Compensation to Relatives Act 1897.
[subs (5) insrt Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1 effective 21 December 1989]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,265] s 11A Award of provisional damages

leg:heading.title: Award of provisional damages

p.text: This section applies to proceedings of the kind referred to in section 11(1) that are brought after the commencement of this section and in which there is proved or admitted to be a chance that at some definite or indefinite time in the future the person who is suffering from the dust-related condition in respect of which the proceedings are brought (the injured person) will, as a result or partly as a result of the breach of duty giving rise to the cause of action, develop another dust-related condition.
The Tribunal may, in accordance with the rules:
award damages assessed on the assumption that the injured person will not develop another dust-related condition, and
award further damages at a future date if the injured person does develop another dust-related condition.
[s 11A insrt Act 21 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 4 effective 1 August 1995]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,270] s 12 Transfer of proceedings from the Supreme Court or District Court to the Tribunal

leg:heading.title: Transfer of proceedings from the Supreme Court or District Court to the Tribunal

p.text: If:
on the commencement of this section, proceedings of the kind referred to in section 11(1) are pending in the Supreme Court and the hearing of those proceedings has not begun, or
after that commencement, proceedings of that kind are brought or are pending in the Supreme Court,
the registrar of the division of that Court in which the proceedings are pending or are brought must transfer the proceedings to the Tribunal, together with any ancillary or related matters.
If:
on the commencement of this section, proceedings of the kind referred to in section 11(1) are pending in the District Court and the hearing of those proceedings has not begun, or
after that commencement, proceedings of that kind are brought or are pending in the District Court,
the registrar of that Court for the place where the proceedings are pending or are brought must transfer the proceedings to the Tribunal, together with any ancillary or related matters.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,275] s 12A No limitation period

leg:heading.title: No limitation period

p.text: The purpose of this section is to enable proceedings to be brought before the Tribunal in relation to dust-related conditions at any time.
Nothing in the Limitation Act 1969 or any other statute of limitations operates to prevent the bringing or maintenance of proceedings before the Tribunal in relation to dust-related conditions.
Without limiting subsection (2):
sections 14 , 18A , 60C and 60G of, Division 6 of Part 2 of, and Schedule 5 to, the Limitation Act 1969 do not prevent the bringing or maintenance of any such proceedings before the Tribunal, and
any such proceedings may be brought or maintained before the Tribunal even though a limitation period has already expired under that Act, and
any such proceedings may be brought or maintained before the Tribunal as if Division 1 of Part 4 of that Act had never been in force.
[subs (3) am Act 92 of 2002 s 3 and Sch 4.1 effective 6 December 2002]
[s 12A insrt Act 130 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 1 effective 1 December 1998]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,280] s 12B Damages for non-economic loss after death of plaintiff

leg:heading.title: Damages for non-economic loss after death of plaintiff

p.text: The purpose of this section is to enable the estate of a person whose death has been caused by a dust-related condition to recover damages for the person's pain or suffering, or for any bodily or mental harm suffered by the person, or for curtailment of the person's expectation of life, provided proceedings commenced by the person were pending before the Tribunal at the person's death.

Section 2(2)(d) of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1944 does not apply in relation to proceedings commenced by a person before his or her death and pending before the Tribunal at his or her death, where the cause of action is for damages in respect of a dust-related condition.
[s 12B insrt Act 130 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 1 effective 1 December 1998]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,285] s 12C Effect of settlement on proceedings by or against joint and several tortfeasors

leg:heading.title: Effect of settlement on proceedings by or against joint and several tortfeasors

p.text: For the avoidance of doubt, settlement with one or more joint tortfeasors in or in relation to proceedings before the Tribunal and who are liable in respect of damage as a result of a dust-related condition is not a bar to recovery against one or more other joint tortfeasors (whether or not they are defendants in the proceedings), unless the terms of the settlement otherwise provide.

A tortfeasor who settles proceedings before the Tribunal that are brought against the tortfeasor by a plaintiff in respect of damage as a result of a dust-related condition is not precluded from recovering contribution in respect of that same damage under section 5(1)(c) of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 from any other tortfeasor (whether a joint tortfeasor or otherwise) who is not a party to the settlement only because a judgment giving effect to that settlement has been entered in favour of the plaintiff without the Tribunal having considered the merits of the case.
This section does not affect the operation or interpretation of section 5(1)(a) of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946.
[s 12C insrt Act 130 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 1 effective 1 December 1998]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,290] s 12D Damages for non-economic loss not to be reduced by certain compensation payments

leg:heading.title: Damages for non-economic loss not to be reduced by certain compensation payments

p.text: This section applies to proceedings before the Tribunal (including proceedings on an appeal from the Tribunal) for damages in relation to dust-related conditions.

In determining damages for non-economic loss in any such proceedings, no deduction is to be made for any amount of compensation already paid or payable, or payable in the future, under the Workers' Compensation (Dust Diseases) Act 1942 .
In this section:
means damages or compensation for the following:
pain and suffering,
loss of amenities of life,
loss of expectation of life,
disfigurement,

the need for services of a domestic nature or services relating to nursing and attendance which have been or are to be provided to a person by another person, and for which the first person has not paid and is not liable to pay any fee or charge.
[s 12D insrt Act 130 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 1 effective 1 December 1998]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,295] s 13 Proceedings before the Tribunal

leg:heading.title: Proceedings before the Tribunal

p.text: The Tribunal must hold its proceedings in open court, except to the extent that the rules provide otherwise.
The President is to fix the times and places for the holding of proceedings before the Tribunal and is to nominate the member before whom proceedings are to be held.
[subs (2) subst Act 21 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 4, effective 19 June 1995; am Act 130 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 1 December 1998]
[subs (3) rep Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 17 August 2005]

If proceedings before the Tribunal have been brought by two or more persons and those proceedings arise out of the same cause of action, the Tribunal may hear and determine those proceedings together if of the opinion that none of those persons' cases would be prejudiced.
A decision of the Tribunal is not liable:
to be vitiated because of any informality or want of form, or
to be questioned or appealed against in any court,
except as provided by section 32 of this Act or section 48 of the Supreme Court Act 1970.
Whenever appropriate, the Tribunal may reconsider any matter that it has previously dealt with, or rescind or amend any decision that the Tribunal has previously made.

If the President is of the opinion that the balance of cost and convenience in the proceedings so requires, the President may direct that the hearing of the proceedings, or any part of the proceedings, take place outside New South Wales.
[subs (7) insrt Act 21 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 4 effective 1 August 1995 ; am Act 130 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 1 effective 1 December 1998]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,300] s 14 Judgments and orders for payment of money

leg:heading.title: Judgments and orders for payment of money

p.text: If a judgment or order of the Tribunal is for payment of an amount of money (including a sum awarded as costs) the judgment or order shall, on the filing of the prescribed documents in the registry of the Common Law Division of the Supreme Court, be taken to be a judgment of that Court for the payment of that amount of money in accordance with the judgment or order of the Tribunal.
For the purposes of subsection (1) , the prescribed documents are:
a copy of the judgment or order of the Tribunal certified by the registrar to be a true copy, and

an affidavit by the person to whom the amount of money was adjudged or ordered to be paid specifying the amount unpaid under the judgment or order and, where the judgment or order is to take effect on a default, as to the making of the default.
No fee is payable for the filing of documents under subsection (1) .
Subsection (3) applies irrespective of the provisions of any other Act to the contrary.
Part 8 (Enforcement of judgments and orders) of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 does not apply to authorise the Tribunal to exercise any function of a court under that Part.
[subs (5) insrt Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 1 July 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,305] s 15 Tribunal may order the payment of interest before damages become payable

leg:heading.title: Tribunal may order the payment of interest before damages become payable

p.text: [s 15 rep Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 17 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,310] s 16 Interest normally payable in respect of unpaid damages

leg:heading.title: Interest normally payable in respect of unpaid damages

p.text: [s 16 rep Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 17 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,315] s 17 Parties to proceedings before the Tribunal

leg:heading.title: Parties to proceedings before the Tribunal

p.text: If a party to proceedings before the Tribunal has a right to proceed against two or more persons who may be jointly liable:
it is sufficient if at least one of those persons is served with process in the proceedings, and
a decision in the proceedings may be given and enforced against the person or persons found to be liable.
Subsection (1) is subject to the rules.
Section 95 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 applies to a decision given in proceedings before the Tribunal in the same way as it applies to a judgment given in proceedings before the Supreme Court.
[subs (3) am Act No 28 of 2005 Sch 5 item [2], effective 15 August 2005]

An executor, administrator, trustee or other legal personal representative may bring or defend proceedings before the Tribunal in the same manner as if he or she were bringing or defending proceedings in his or her own right.

If, before the holding of particular proceedings before the Tribunal or at any stage during the holding of any proceedings, the Tribunal is of the opinion that a person ought to be joined as a party to the proceedings, the Tribunal may, by notice in writing served on the person or by oral direction given during the proceedings, join the person as a party to the proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,320] s 18 Notice and conduct of proceedings

leg:heading.title: Notice and conduct of proceedings

p.text: [s 18 rep Act 21 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 4, effective 1 August 1995]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,325] s 19 Right of appearance and representation before the Tribunal

leg:heading.title: Right of appearance and representation before the Tribunal

p.text: A party to proceedings before the Tribunal:
may appear in the proceedings personally or by an Australian legal practitioner; and
may not, except by leave of the Tribunal, be represented in the proceedings otherwise than by an Australian legal practitioner.
[subs (1) am Act 58 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3.5[1], effective 20 June 2006]
Only an Australian legal practitioner is entitled to demand or receive a fee or reward for representing a party in proceedings before the Tribunal.
[subs (2) am Act 58 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3.5[1], effective 20 June 2006]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,330] s 20 Subpoenas and examination of witnesses

leg:heading.title: Subpoenas and examination of witnesses

p.text: If the Tribunal so directs or a party to proceedings before the Tribunal so requests, the registrar must issue a subpoena requiring a specified person to do either or both of the following:
to attend and give evidence before the Tribunal at a time and place specified in the subpoena,

to produce to the Tribunal, or to attend before the Tribunal and produce, any document or thing in the person's custody or under the person's control that the person is required by the subpoena to produce.
If:
in accordance with this section, a person is required by a subpoena to produce a document, and
the document is not in writing, or is not written in the English language, or is not decipherable on sight,

the subpoena shall be taken to require the person to produce, in addition to the document if it is in writing, or instead of the document if it is not in writing, a statement, written in the English language and decipherable on sight, containing the whole of the information in the document.

The Tribunal may administer an oath to any person appearing as a witness before the Tribunal, whether or not a subpoena has been issued to the witness under subsection (1) , and allow the witness to be examined and cross-examined on oath.

A witness attending or appearing before the Tribunal has the same protection and, without affecting any penalty that may be imposed under this Act, is subject to the same liabilities, as a witness would have or be subject to in proceedings before the Supreme Court.

A witness attending before the Tribunal in accordance with a subpoena issued under subsection (1) is entitled to be paid such fees and allowances as are prescribed by, or calculated in accordance with, the rules.

If a subpoena is issued under subsection (1) at the request of a party, the person specified in the subpoena is not required to comply with the subpoena unless, not later than a reasonable time before the day on which the subpoena is to be complied with, that person is tendered an amount, prescribed by, or calculated in accordance with, the rules, to meet the expense of complying with the requirements of the subpoena.
This section is subject to the regulations.
[subs (7) insrt Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 1 July 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,335] s 21 Person issued with a subpoena may be apprehended

leg:heading.title: Person issued with a subpoena may be apprehended

p.text: If a person served with a subpoena issued under section 20(1) to attend before, or to produce a document to, the Tribunal fails to comply with the subpoena, the Tribunal may, on proof of the service of the subpoena, issue to such person as the Tribunal appoints a warrant for the apprehension of that person.
A warrant issued under this section authorises:
the apprehension of the person to whom the warrant relates, and
the bringing of that person before the Tribunal, and
the detention of that person in custody until he or she is released by order of the Tribunal or the Supreme Court.

The apprehension of a person under this section does not relieve the person from any liability incurred as a result of non-compliance with a subpoena to attend before, or to produce a document or thing to, the Tribunal.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,340] s 22 Inspection and retention of records

leg:heading.title: Inspection and retention of records

p.text: The Tribunal:
may inspect any document or statement produced before it and retain it for such period as it thinks necessary for the purposes of the proceedings in relation to which it was produced, and
may make copies of the document or statement or any part of the document or statement.

If a document or statement is produced before, and retained by, the Tribunal, the person otherwise entitled to possession of the document or statement is, on request, entitled to be supplied, as soon as practicable, with a copy of the document or statement certified by the registrar to be a true copy.
A document or statement so certified is admissible as evidence in all courts as if it were the original document or statement.

If, in accordance with subsection (2), a person is entitled to be supplied with a copy of a document or statement, the person, or a person authorised by the person, may, at such times and places as the registrar directs, inspect and make copies of, or take extracts from, the document or statement.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,345] s 23 Informal proof and admissions

leg:heading.title: Informal proof and admissions

p.text: [s 23 rep Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 17 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,350] s 24 Examination de bene esse

leg:heading.title: Examination de bene esse

p.text: The Tribunal may, on the application of a party to proceedings before it, authorise:
any judge, counsel, attorney or commissioner for affidavits, whether of New South Wales or elsewhere, or
any British Consular Officer or Australian Consular Officer in any place out of New South Wales,
to take at some convenient place the examination of a witness de bene esse, if the witness:
is absent from New South Wales, or
is expected to die or to be unable from sickness or infirmity to attend at the hearing of the proceedings.
[subs (1) am Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2 effective 7 July 2003]
In subsection (1) , the expressions “Australian Consular Officer” and “British Consular Officer” have the same meanings as they have in section 26 of the Oaths Act 1900.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,355] s 25 Evidence in proceedings before the Tribunal

leg:heading.title: Evidence in proceedings before the Tribunal

p.text: Any evidence that would be admissible in proceedings in the Supreme Court is admissible in proceedings before the Tribunal.
Except as otherwise provided by this Part or the rules, evidence is not admissible in proceedings before the Tribunal if it would not be admissible in those proceedings by virtue of subsection (1) .

Historical evidence and general medical evidence concerning dust exposure and dust diseases which has been admitted in any proceedings before the Tribunal may, with the leave of the Tribunal, be received as evidence in any other proceedings before the Tribunal, whether or not the proceedings are between the same parties.
[subs (3) insrt Act 21 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 4 effective 1 August 1995]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,360] s 25A Material already obtained

leg:heading.title: Material already obtained

p.text: Material obtained for the purposes of proceedings before the Tribunal by discovery or interrogatories may:
with the leave of the Tribunal, and
with the consent of:
subject to subparagraph (ii), the party who originally obtained the material or the party's Australian legal practitioner, or
another person prescribed by the rules,
be used in other proceedings before the Tribunal, whether or not the proceedings are between the same parties.
The rules may provide that subsection (1) does not apply in specified kinds of proceedings or in specified circumstances.
[s 25A insrt Act 130 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 1 effective 1 December 1998; am Act 58 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3.5[2], effective 20 June 2006]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,365] s 25B General issues already determined

leg:heading.title: General issues already determined

p.text: Issues of a general nature determined in proceedings before the Tribunal (including proceedings on an appeal from the Tribunal) may not be relitigated or reargued in other proceedings before the Tribunal without the leave of the Tribunal, whether or not the proceedings are between the same parties.

If an issue of a general nature already determined in proceedings before the Tribunal (the earlier proceedings) is the subject of other proceedings before the Tribunal (the later proceedings) and that issue is determined in the later proceedings on the basis of the determination of the issue in the earlier proceedings, the judgment of the Tribunal in the later proceedings must identify the issue and must identify that it is an issue of a general nature determined as referred to in this section.
[subs (1A) insrt Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 1 July 2005]
In deciding whether to grant leave for the purposes of subsection (1), the Tribunal is to have regard to:
the availability of new evidence (whether or not previously available), and
the manner in which the other proceedings referred to in that subsection were conducted, and
such other matters as the Tribunal considers to be relevant.
The rules may provide that subsection (1) does not apply in specified kinds of proceedings or in specified circumstances or (without limitation) in relation to specified kinds of issues.
This section does not affect any other law relating to matters of which judicial notice can be taken or about which proof is not required.
[s 25B insrt Act 130 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 1 effective 1 December 1998]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,370] s 26 Contempt of the Tribunal

leg:heading.title: Contempt of the Tribunal

p.text: In respect of proceedings before the Tribunal, the Tribunal has the same powers for punishing contempt of the Tribunal as are conferred on a Judge of the Supreme Court for punishing contempt of a division of the Supreme Court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,375] s 27 Dismissal of frivolous etc proceedings

leg:heading.title: Dismissal of frivolous etc proceedings

p.text: [s 27 rep Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 17 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,380] s 28 Tribunal to provide reasons for its decisions

leg:heading.title: Tribunal to provide reasons for its decisions

p.text: [s 28 rep Act 21 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 4 effective 1 August 1995]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,385] s 29 Tribunal may award costs

leg:heading.title: Tribunal may award costs

p.text: [s 29 rep Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 17 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,390] s 30 Service of documents

leg:heading.title: Service of documents

p.text: [s 30 rep Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 17 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,395] s 31 Tribunal may give procedural directions in certain cases

leg:heading.title: Tribunal may give procedural directions in certain cases

p.text: [s 31 rep Act 22 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 17 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [470,400] s 32 Right of appeal to Supreme Court

leg:heading.title: Right of appeal to Supreme Court

p.text: A party who is dissatisfied with a decision of the Tribunal in point of law or on a question as to the admission or rejection of evidence may appeal to the Supreme Court.

The Supreme Court may, on the hearing of any appeal under this section, remit the matter to the Tribunal for determination by the Tribunal in accordance with any decision of the Supreme Court and may make such other order in relation to the appeal as the Supreme Court sees fit.
A decision of the Supreme Court on an appeal under this section is binding on the Tribunal and on all parties to the proceedings in respect of which the appeal was made.
The following appeals under this section may be made only by leave of the Supreme Court:
an appeal from an interlocutory decision,
an appeal from a decision as to costs only,
an appeal from a final decision, other than an appeal that involves (directly or indirectly) a claim for, or a question relating to, an amount of $20,000 or more,
an appeal from a decision made with the consent of the parties.
[subs (4) am Act 99 of 2002 s 3 and Sch 3 effective 20 December 2002]
[s 32 subst Act 49 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 11 effective 4 December 1998]
